channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

image.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition

channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: The United States is 'looking at' banning TikTok and other Chinese social media apps, Pompeo says
item.description: The United States is "looking at" banning Chinese social media apps, including TikTok, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said Monday.

item.title: UK foreign secretary warns China 'can't be trusted' as London passes Magnitsky sanctions law
item.description: British Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab has questioned whether China can be trusted to live up to international obligations after its move to introduce a new security law for Hong Kong, which London says contravenes the historical agreement handing over the territory to Beijing.

item.title: Why TikTok's fate is in jeopardy in this country
item.description: India is TikTok's top market for new downloads, and parent-company ByteDance had forecast $1 billion in advertising revenue there this year. Now India's ban on Chinese apps has put TikTok's fate in jeopardy in one of the fastest-growing markets in the world. CNN's Sherisse Pham reports.

item.title: TikTok is leaving Hong Kong after national security law goes into effect
item.description: TikTok says it will exit Hong Kong, joining other big tech firms that have expressed wariness about operating in the Asian financial hub after China imposed a controversial national security law there.

item.title: Melbourne going back into lockdown for 6 weeks as cases surge
Hong Kong schools told to remove books that violate new law as police powers extended
Citizens collectively ring pots when this world leader goes on TV
item.description: In the age of Covid-19, President Donald Trump and Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro are two of a kind. CNN's Bill Weir reports on how the US and Brazil lead the world in the number of cases while their leaders downplay coronavirus.

item.title: Trump turns clock back 155 years with Confederacy-inspired election strategy
item.description: One-fifth of the way through the 21st Century, Donald Trump is seemingly running to be the last President of the Confederacy.

item.title: The US is in a 'free fall' with Covid-19, doctors warn
The mask decision that will haunt Trump's reelection bid
item.description: As coronavirus cases surge and governors begin agitating for a national mandate on wearing masks, President Donald Trump is showing few signs he'll budge on an issue that has come to epitomize a national pandemic response rooted in denial and which now threatens his political future.

item.title: Top Obama strategist explains why Trump's tactics aren't working
item.description: White House press secretary Kayleigh McEnany refused to denounce the Confederate flag during a press briefing after President Donald Trump bemoaned NASCAR's recent decision to ban it from all races and events. CNN's David Axelrod analyzes Trump's strategy of stoking racial divide in the nation to gain re-election.

item.title: US may deport international students whose universities switch to online-only learning
item.description: International students who are pursuing degrees in the United States will have to leave the country or risk deportation if their universities switch to online-only courses, Immigration and Customs Enforcement announced Monday.

item.title: Brazil opens itself up, to everything except masks
Samsung says profit jumped 23%, likely thanks to strong chip demand
item.description: Samsung, the world's largest smartphone maker, predicts its profit jumped more than 20% last quarter, suggesting that the company has managed to withstand the fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: China steps up dispute with Japan over Tokyo-controlled islands
item.description: Chinese coast guard ships have twice intruded into Japan's territorial waters in the past four days, forcing Japanese coast guard vessels to block the Chinese ships from approaching Japanese fishing boats on at least one occasion, authorities in Tokyo said Monday.

item.title: Siberia had its warmest June ever as wildfires raged and carbon dioxide emissions surged
item.description: An estimated 59 megatonnes of carbon dioxide were released across Siberia in June by wildfires raging across the vast Russian region, according to scientists at the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS).

item.title: Tensions heat up in South China Sea as US makes significant show of force
item.description: For the first time in six years, two US Navy aircraft carriers are in the South China Sea, the latest show of military might from Washington as it pushes back against China's sweeping claim to much of the contested region.

item.title: Anderson Cooper: Trump wants you to suck it up as thousands die
item.description: CNN's Anderson Cooper slams President Donald Trump's comment that coronavirus is "99% harmless" while the number of cases in the US continue to rise.

item.title: Why is Mexico's President flying commercial to meet Trump?
item.description: If you happen to be flying between Mexico City and Washington, DC, this week, you could be seatmates with a president.

item.title: I got Covid-19 two months ago. I'm still discovering new areas of damage
item.description: The cough has come back, without warning and seemingly for no reason; so has the fatigue. True, neither are as debilitating as when I had the actual virus, but they are back.

item.title: Explosive Trump tell-all book by his niece to be released early
item.description: A tell-all book by President Trump's niece Mary, a licensed clinical psychologist, will now be published next week, two weeks earlier than expected, the publisher Simon & Schuster said Monday.

item.title: Prince Harry and Meghan speak out on UK's colonial past
item.description: Prince Harry and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, have encouraged the UK to reckon with its colonial past, highlighting the "wrongs" of its historic involvement in the countries that now make up the Commonwealth.

item.title: Australia to seal off 6.6 million people in virus-hit state as outbreak worsens
Halle Berry apologizes and is no longer considering a transgender role in upcoming film
item.description: After facing backlash on social media, actress Halle Berry announced on Twitter Monday she is no longer considering portraying a transgender man in an upcoming film role.

item.title: Fox News cropped Trump out of photo with Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, then called it a mistake
item.description: Fox News said on Monday that it "mistakenly" cropped President Trump out of a photograph that featured the accused sex-trafficker Jeffrey Epstein and his alleged accomplice Ghislaine Maxwell.

item.title: White woman who called police on Black birdwatcher in Central Park charged
item.description: The woman who was caught on video accusing a Central Park birdwatcher of threatening her will be prosecuted, the Manhattan district attorney said Monday.

item.title: Protester struck by car during a Black Lives Matter demonstration in Indiana
item.description: A vehicle hit at least one person at a Black Lives Matter protest in Bloomington, Indiana, as it was ending Monday evening.

item.title: This country is bucking Latin America's virus trend, here's how
item.description: Uruguay has been successfully managing its coronavirus outbreak, an outlier in a region that is being badly hit by the pandemic. CNN's Patrick Oppmann reports.

item.title: Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes signs most lucrative sports deal in history, agent says
item.description: The NFL's Kansas City Chiefs have signed their quarterback Patrick Mahomes to a 10-year contract extension that his agent says is the most lucrative contract in sports history.

item.title: This glacier is turning pink, and that's bad news
item.description: A glacier in Italy is turning pink because of algae -- a development that will make the ice melt faster, a scientist studying the phenomenon says.

item.title: Agencies seem to be afraid to talk about virus being airborne, expert says
item.description: Imagine a noisy, crowded bar. Music is pounding, and people are clustered close together, talking loudly or even shouting to be heard. If it's cold out, doors and windows are shut tight and the heat is on, or if it's hot out, everything is shut and the air conditioner is recirculating the air.

item.title: Something else is spiking in California other than coronavirus
item.description: More than 800 cases of anti-Asian hate incidents have been reported in California. CNN's Sara Sidner reports.

item.title: Elon Musk sells short shorts in jab at investors
item.description: Tesla is having a great year. Its stock is up 200% in 2020, its market value now exceeds every other carmaker on the planet, as well as Disney and Coke. CEO Elon Musk may truly have proved Tesla's haters wrong.

item.title: American Airlines mechanic accused of smuggling cocaine but his attorney says authorities have the wrong guy
item.description: A longtime American Airlines mechanic is accused of using his access to secure areas of an airport to smuggle cocaine into the US in an airplane compartment, according to a criminal complaint filed in February. His attorney says authorities have the wrong guy.

item.title: Video shows packed lake party in US despite warnings
item.description: Video from a water park in Wisconsin, and parties in Lake of the Ozarks, Missouri, and Diamond Lake, Michigan, shows large groups of people celebrating the Fourth of July holiday despite warnings from health officials that such gatherings would likely lead to an increase in coronavirus cases. CNN's Polo Sandoval reports.

item.title: WNBA players will wear uniforms that honor the women and girls lost to police brutality and racial violence
item.description: This season's WNBA players hope that before you chant their names, you'll remember the victims of police and racial violence too.

item.title: Here's the best way to take care of your mental health during the pandemic
item.description: As the US grapples with Covid-19, its economic fallout, and the continuing anguish of racial injustice, many of us are struggling with our mental health. A Census Bureau survey found that one in three Americans are now reporting symptoms of depression or anxiety -- more than three times the rate from a similar survey conducted in the first half of 2019.

item.title: Meet the 'tiny bug slayer,' an ancient relative of giant dinosaurs
item.description: A "tiny bug slayer" that only reached 4 inches in height was the ancestor of much larger dinosaurs and flying pterosaurs 237 million years ago, according to a new study.

item.title: Georg Baselitz experiments with 'chance and disorder' in new paintings
item.description: Enigmatic figures appear in a succession of poetic poses across 13 large canvases. Sometimes separate and at other times touching, the works are part of a series of oil paintings by German painter Georg Baselitz, unveiled at the recently reopened Gagosian Gallery in Hong Kong.

item.title: These senior Indian couples found love again. Not everyone is happy about it
item.description: Evening is Asawari Kulkarni's favorite time of the day. She spends it sipping green tea with her new partner Anil Yardi.

item.title: How one diver became the 'shark whisperer'
item.description: Cristina Zenato needs only two words to describe sharks—nature's masterpiece. A professional diver in the Bahamas, she loves sharks. Especially the Caribbean reef sharks that flourish around Grand Bahama Island, thanks in large part to her efforts to protect them. The sharks swim right up to the woman known as the "shark whisperer" and nuzzle against her while she pets them like they're dogs or cats. Great Big Story takes a dive off Grand Bahama Island with Zenato to learn how she built such a strong bond with these beautiful creatures.

item.title: From Disney to NASCAR, brands are breaking away from Trump's racial rhetoric
item.description: A version of this article first appeared in the "Reliable Sources" newsletter. You can sign up for free right here.

item.title: Everyday words and phrases that have racist connotations
item.description: The words and phrases permeate nearly every aspect of our society.

item.title: What it's like to visit a country that doesn't exist
item.description: For various complicated reasons, a number of self-declared countries around the world aren't officially recognized -- some are even left off maps. Brazilian author Guilherme Canever has been to many of them and documented his adventures in a new book.

item.title: Searching for the real 'Gullah Gullah Island'
item.description: Remember 'Gullah Gullah Island,' the beloved Nick Jr. television show from the '90s? Well, while the island is a fictional place, the culture and people that inspired the show are real. The kids program is based on the traditions of the Gullah Geechee people, direct descendants of enslaved West Africans who created a unique culture and regional dialect that has been passed on through generations.

item.title: Your security camera may be telling burglars when you're not home
item.description: Some popular home security cameras could allow would-be burglars to work out when you've left the building, according to a study published Monday.

item.title: Vogue Portugal drops widely slammed 'madness' cover depicting woman in a psychiatric hospital
item.description: Vogue Portugal has dropped one of the front covers of its July / August issue, after it was widely slammed online.

item.title: Mona Lisa is back but without the crowds as the Louvre reopens
item.description: The world's most popular museum, the Louvre, has reopened its doors after months of closure, but while visiting it will now be a slightly different experience, its star attraction should at least be free of crowds.

item.title: Hong Kong schools told to remove books that violate new law
item.description: Schools in Hong Kong have been told that they must remove books and teaching materials that could violate the sweeping national security law that was imposed by Beijing last week, sparking concerns over mounting censorship in the city.

item.title: Facebook, Google and Twitter won't give Hong Kong authorities user data for now
item.description: Facebook and its messaging service WhatsApp will stop processing requests for user data made by Hong Kong law enforcement authorities while they carry out an assessment of a controversial security law imposed by China on the city.
